Params: By the time the Cerberus members push the car to a place that "looks like" a mechanic's shop, the sun is already setting behind the distant hills.
A cracked, lopsided billboard stands outside a scruffy plywood shed under the dusk sky. Crooked letters in white are painted across the sign—"Motors & Supper".
Pieces of torn fabric are tied above the board and the shed, attracting "customers" as they wave in the dusty wind.
That billboard was very likely an advertisement for products that were... a little unsavory in nature.
Tch... That's no ordinary can. Turn away, kid.
Is this really a mechanic's shop? Our broken car is worth more than this shed.
Noctis sneers, jumping down the seat.
How big of a scam can this be?
No. 21 lies on the roof of the car, stretching.
Hmm... It smells like engine oil.
Let's stop wasting time in a place like this.
You. Go ask around and get the car fixed.
I spent the most time pushing the car on the road. Why do I still need to do this?
I thought you wanted to know how big of a scam this can be.
I don't think this is too much of a challenge to the "invincible" Noctis, right?
Vera teases Noctis as she steps into the car and sits on his resting seat.
Tch, what a chore. Listen, don't blame me if things go wrong.
Now, sit and behold how charismatic I can be.
Noctis shrugs and steps over the old tires, bearings, and rubber tubes that litter the floor, heading toward the raggedy garage.
Noctis enters the shed, accompanied by the sound of metal parts hitting each other. This place looks as dilapidated inside as it is outside.
Although its interior is slightly tidier, it is filled with rusty display shelves, doors, and walls covered in green, oxidized copper, making it way less comfortable than the expansive exterior.
An even stronger stench of engine oil mixes with the scent of rotting flesh, threatening to coalesce into water droplets and drip down the light bulb beneath its dim, warm hue.
And yet, classical music has been playing in this place all this time in drastic contrast to how it looks.

A man stands behind the glass display counter. He is wearing an apron as colorful as a painter's palette, so vivid that it is a little touch-up away from serving as the hottest abstract artwork in a gallery.
Yo. We need our car fixed.
The man does not seem to notice Noctis' presence. He quietly smokes his cigarette while reading a colorful and crude magazine.
A smoke ring rises to the ceiling as if trying desperately to escape this awful place, but all it can do in the end is disperse among the rusted metal.
Hey! I said we need our car fixed!
What would you like to eat?
We want to fix our car! Did you hear me?
Order food first. Then we can talk about your car.
The owner takes out an oily laminated paper from the counter and hands it to Noctis.
Authentic seafood paella! Guaranteed satisfaction with your aquatic fantasies!
Ham and mashed potatoes sandwiches! Your best friend at home and on the road!
Heartwarming specialty steaks! Fill your stomach and your soul!
Noctis glances at a metal hook hanging from the ceiling on the other side of the shed. A piece of meat dangles there, covered in darkened soot and fluorescent green.
This could be seafood, ham, or even a piece of steak.
I'm not eating anything! I'm here to get my car fixed!
Only now does the owner look up and stare at Noctis through his thick glasses.
Tch. A Construct, is it? We can skip the food, then.
It'll cost you this much. Cash only.
The owner reaches up and knocks on the number written on the crooked cardboard behind him—
There's another shop 100 km north of here if you want to take your car somewhere else.
The owner blows another smoke ring casually.
Noctis would not have stood for this kind of provocation normally, but his good sense has prevented him from smashing the owner's glasses into pieces.
Neither he, No. 21, nor Vera wants to push the car for another 100 km.
With that in mind, Noctis purposefully places his left arm on top of the counter, displaying his brawny robotic arm.
Hey, have you heard of Babylonia? Do you know about Cerberus?
The owner does not seem to notice that Noctis can probably kill him with one punch using that robotic arm, and he continues to read his magazine.
Babylonia, Boogaloonia, Cerberus, pompous, dingus... I have nothing to do with any of them.
There are a few troublemakers south of here. Go take care of it.
Huh? Who do you think you are? Why would I listen to your order?
He points at the cardboard behind him again.
Take care of the rascals that have been disrupting my business, and I'll fix your car.
Noctis tightens his fists furiously, and the cracking sound coming from his fingers sounds almost like he is crushing the man's glasses.
You don't have to go. Why don't I give you a discount since you're from Boogaloonia or something? 71 thousand, and I'll throw in a seafood paella as well.
Once again, the owner does not seem to acknowledge the Construct before him, simply indulging in his illustrated magazine.
Our car better be fixed after this, or else!
Do you have money? Has to be cash.
Who brings cash on a mission?
21? You hiding any cash in your sleeves?
Is there nothing but bombs in your head? We Cerberus share one bank account, idiot.
And I asked you how it went!
The butcher-like owner said he'd fix our car after we deal with some Corrupted for him.
Alright, then. Go ahead. We'll wait here.
What should I have done? 72 thousand! And I'd have to order seafood that costs 3.5 grand that looks like shit!
Cerberus names the price, not the other way around. Isn't that right, Noctis?
Vera teases him, but he does not notice the fury in her voice.
He dropped it to 71 thousand and threw in a free paella, but I thought we'd probably be more interested in some physical activities, right?
...Alright. The money's coming out of your pocket.
Vera is about to shatter the banner spear in her hand.
Your vital fluid pressure is approaching the threshold, Captain.
But that guy doesn't look intimidated by us. He's not even scared of Babylonia.
That's because you look dumb, Noctis. No one's scared of you.
I bet I could convince him to drop it to 70 thousand instead.
You thought your grenade-sized brain could—
Constructs do not need to breathe, but Vera's M.I.N.D. directs her to inhale deeply at this point before exhaling.
Where do we need to go? I'd love to punch something right now.
